Sirs, I have tried mailing you but your link is not working. What it is, I am wrting a non profit book on behalf of the Borders Family History Society with all proceeds going to them The book os on the ecclesiastical ruins of the Scottish Borders and copies will be gifted to the High Schools within the region. I plan to include some details from your site where copyright and courtesy will be fully shown. I had originally intended to planned to sell the book to the public to make more people aware of their heritage and, of course, raising more funds for BFHS. Since reading your site, I decided to contact you. My book will contain 99.9% of what is already in the Public Domain and a little from your database which I can assure is very minimal. It is not a commercial venture in the sense I shall not make money, it is entirely to help provide funds for the BFHS and of course schools and libraries. I would like to know if you find this acceptable.
Kind regards,
James Denham

item.title: Incomplete characterizations of POMS's
item.dc:creator: abeam
item.content:encoded:
In charter 31, p.23-5 in Registrum Episcopatus Moraviensis, Edinburgh: Bannatyne Club, 1837, witnesses occur:
"Archebaldo de Dufphus milite". In the database you have an Archibald of Duffus for this charter, but without mention of the fact that he was a knight. "William dean of Strathbogie", who you have signing charter 69, is also the "W . decano de Strathbolgi" of charter 31. In your description of the charter you mention this, but not under William himself.
PS. Your e-mail address bounces.

item.title: Problem with the location Raby (Durham)
item.dc:creator: mhammond
item.content:encoded:
Hi! I'm a graduate student in the States researching Holme Cultram abbey near Carlisle. In at least three of your records, PoMS, H2/135/8, PoMS, H2/132/23, PoMS, H2/131/38 you place the location 'Raby' in Durham. This would be an extremely far from the monastery's other possessions, and is most likely a confusion stemming from the full place name of the monastery, which is "the Island of Holme and Raby". This is noted in "The Transactions of the Cumberland and Westmoreland Antiquarian and Archaeological Society, volume 5" (1881), p. 136, and the place name Raby near Abbeytown (that is, the abbey of Holme Cultram) is still visible on the 7th edition 1"=1mi ordinance survey map.
It was a seeming error that sidetracked me for a while, so I thought you'd like to know.
Cheers, Leland Grigoli

item.title: Cannot find someone who should be in the database
item.dc:creator: abeam
item.content:encoded:
Cannot find: re Alexander Dunbar. There are other unimportant references to him, and he was alive on 26 June 1331, when his son Sir Patrick quit-claimed his rights in Swinwood to the monks of Coldingham. It is not known when he died. His seal, still attached to one of the receipts for his fee, shows a lion rampant within a double tressure. Legend, 'S. ALEXANDRI FILII COMITIS DE DYNB.. The name of his wife is nowhere stated. Sir Alexander had issue, so far as is known, one son
Source: Scots Peerage or Burke's 106th ed.

item.title: Presentation suggestions
item.dc:creator: mhammond
item.content:encoded: Having now used the very useful PoMS database a bit, here are some suggestions which could help to improve it: - have a brief explanation of the terms on the Search page. Then include notes at the bottom or 'where to find' on the results page e.g. explanation of factoids, abbreviations such as counties - Factoid - I've not found an explanation of what the various ones are (even in teh answer to the question in FAQs!) in the tutorial or elsewhere - relationship factoid - split blood/familial ones from tenant, employment etc - Familial Relationships: explain carefully or change the way these are expressed e.g. for Berewald Fleming, it's shown as "Grandfather of Walter, son of John, son of Berewald Fleming" - Dominus - is one term not in the Glossary along with factoid etc

item.title: are there one or two men called Elias, clerk and/or canon of Glasgow?
item.content:encoded: Dear PoMS, I've been using the database for an archaeological report and while it's rather confusing to navigate, I've been using the documents as they are handily all in one place. However - I've been using doc PoMS H2/7/9 which is the augmentation of the prebend of Govan by bishop Herbert of Glasgow, 1147 X 1162, at http://db.poms.ac.uk/record/source/1185/; accessed 12 June 2017 The relationship factoids say that Elias of Partick, clerk adn canon of Glasgow, fl1159 x 98, PoMS, No 926, at http://db.poms.ac.uk/record/person/926/ seems to be the same person as one Helias who is also a canon (known under a variety of spellings - Elia, Hela, Helia). Helias/Elias the canon, according to Norman Shead, is a different person from Helias the clerk who assumes the prebend of Govan. The dating of PoMS H2/7/9 is suggested by the PoMS relationship factoid, no. 12120, http://db.poms.ac.uk/record/factoid/12120/; accessed 20 June 2017. This states that 'Helia [sic] as canon, which he was by 6 Jan. 1161 Ã— 13 Sept. 1162 (Glas. Reg., no.16)'. Are there two different Eliases, or why is there not a separate entry for Helia, the canon in relationship factoid no 12120? Is this assumed to be a later position occupied by Elias the clerk, prebendary of Govan? Are they two different people (according to Shead they are - see SEA index p370, both listed as Helia with note they are indistinguishable). I cannot find an entry for Helia in the database only for Elias - I'm trying to narrow the date range for the augmentation of the prebend of Govan, in connection with the excavation of the site of Partick Castle. Many thanks

item.title: Does PoMS use date as given in doc or modern style
item.content:encoded:
Could you tell me if the docs are dated OS or NS? Specifically, doc PoMS, H2/7/98 (http://db.poms.ac.uk/record/source/6969/; accessed 28 June 2017) is dated in the original 1832 publication (Registrum Monasterii de Passelet, p204), as Jan 1296; the PoMS entry dates it 1296 as well, and it is cited by Dalglish, C and Driscoll, S 2009, Scottish Burgh Survey: Historic Govan, 19 cites the date 1297.
I presume the date is 1296 (OS), 1297 (NS), and usually cited as 1296/97, being before Lady Day, that is before the end 1296 by the old calendar when the year was reckoned to 25 March, and before the new year.
How does PoMS date things - by the date used on the document, or does it update material to modern, NS Julian calendar dating? Dalglish and Driscoll have presumably updated the year to 1297, but not stated this.

item.title: Ralph de Lascels, knight in 1349
item.content:encoded: I am working to provide more indexes on this website: aalt.law.uh.edu - English, not Scottish stuff; and I use Google to assist in verifying names; Your website got a hit when I searched for "Lascels(?), Ralph de, knight", seen in 1349, in this image: http://aalt.law.uh.edu/E3/CP40no359/bCP40no359mm1dtoEnd/IMG_9007.htm ... so thanks !! as defendant.

item.content:encoded: Richard de Chesehelme (Cheiselm) A description of his seal is given with a reference - Catalogue: P/Chis/1. Notes SWII p.284. Please explain what the catalogue and notes references mean. I would like to see this seal - or at least an image of it.

item.title: Incorrect links to Matthew Hammons's "Women in the Ragman Roll''
item.content:encoded:
Hi
I've been reading through your great features.
Thought I would let you know that the links to Matthew Hammond's "Women in the Ragman Roll'' are linked the wrong way around, that is Part One opens Part Two, and Part Two opens Part One.
Thank you for publishing your wonderful research.

item.title: Possible identification
item.content:encoded: Wouldn't "Unknown, constable of Urquhart (http://db.poms.ac.uk/record/person/18122/#)" be attributable to William FitzWarin, who has holding the castle of behalf of the English in 1297?

item.title: maps?
item.dc:creator: mhammond
item.content:encoded: Dear POMS team, first of all I'd just like to say how impressive your achievement is and how envious I feel. I am particularly impressed by the Labs section, and your attempt to explore news to represent the data. What I can't seem to fing though os any cartography, for example, a map of where a particular individual was active. Is it, perhaps, that I have failed to find the corresonding tool? or is this something you have in the pipeline? thanks in advance and congratulations, David

item.title: Searching for Hugh de Morville.
item.dc:creator: mhammond
item.content:encoded: When seeking information on Hugh de Morville I entered his name in the Search Option and was informed that there 'no results'. Being very close to King David I find this surprising.

item.title: Great thanks and gratitude!
item.dc:creator: mhammond
item.content:encoded: I just wanted to give my utmost thanks to all involved in creating this database. It has proven a remarkable and invaluable resource for my family history research, not to mention has lit such a fire in me to learn more about this most interesting and complex time in both Scottish and English history. My family, the de Conisbrough's (now Kinniburgh) was so very difficult to research, due to the amazing amount of different spellings, and this website has made all the difference in putting together the pieces of their journey from Yorkshire to the lowlands of Scotland as Novo Homines of Malcolm IV. Thank you all for your amazing work!

item.title: Regarding the dating of the grant of the church of Staplegordon to Kelso Abbey.
item.dc:creator: mhammond
item.content:encoded: Greetings from Canada! I have a question regarding the dating of the gift of the church of Staplegordon by William de Conisbrough. Your website gives a firm date to the document as 4 July 1195 and a possible date of 1193. My understanding of the firm date is that it's actually the date that William I comfirmed the renewal of churches and alms within the diocese of Glasgow by Jocelin, the bishop of Glasgow. But I also came across another document on the PoMS site from the Scotia Pontificia, no. 114, dated 25 March 1182, where Pope Lucius III is reconfirming the papal protection to Kelso abbey and all its possessions. Among those possessions listed is the church of Staplegordon. The original grant by William de Conisbrough is stated as a gift, not a reconfirmation of a previous grant. Also, in a article from the late 1930's R.C. Reid noted that the wording of the grant suggested that William de Conisbrough built the church that he granted. This was also mentioned by Richard Oram in Domination and Lordship : Scotland, 1070-1230, p.322. So my question is whether it's possible that someone prior to William could have donated the church to Kelso or if the date of 25 March 1182 is a safe latest possible date for me to attach to William's granting of this church? A long winded question regarding an obscure place, I know. But it bears much meaning to me in my research and any aid you can offer it greatly appreciated!
